name: Jessica Mehta
bio:
Born and raised in Oregon, Jessica Mehta is a member of the Cherokee Nation. A first-generation college student, she earned her BA in English and MSc in Writing from Portland State University. She is the author of four collections of poetry, including Secret Telling Bones (2017) and What Makes an Always (2015). She’s also published the novel The Wrong Kind of Indian (2017).
The winner of a grant from the Money for Women/Barbara Deming Memorial Fund in Poetry and the Potlatch Award for Native Artists, Mehta was a winner of the National Center for American Indian Enterprise Development’s 40 Under 40 award. She’s the founder of the Jessica Tyner Scholarship Fund, which supports students pursuing an advanced degree in English and creative writing with a Native American connection. 
Mehta is the president of VoiceCatcher, a journal championing of the work of female-identified writers in the Pacific Northwest, and a teacher of creative writing, including at the Loft Literary Center and Literary Arts. She also runs a writing and editing service called MehtaFor.
